questions.text: Which amino acid is not used for synthesis of hormones?
questions.solution:
While tyrosine, phenylalanine, and tryptophan are all amino acids that can serve as precursors for hormone synthesis, glycine does not directly participate in hormone synthesis pathways. Instead, glycine is important for other biochemical processes in the body, including protein synthesis and as a component of various metabolic pathways.

Among the amino acids listed, glycine (option d) is the amino acid that is not directly used for the synthesis of hormones. Here's an explanation for each option:

a. Tyrosine:

  • Tyrosine is a non-essential amino acid that serves as a precursor for the synthesis of several important hormones such as thyroid hormones (thyroxine and triiodothyronine), catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine), and melanin.

b. Phenylalanine:

  • Phenylalanine is an essential amino acid that can be converted to tyrosine in the body through the action of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. Tyrosine, in turn, serves as a precursor for hormone synthesis as mentioned above.

c. Tryptophan:

  • Tryptophan is an essential amino acid and serves as a precursor for the synthesis of several hormones and neurotransmitters, including serotonin and melatonin.

d. Glycine:

  • Glycine is a non-essential amino acid that is not directly involved in the synthesis of hormones. Instead, glycine is primarily involved in protein synthesis and serves as a precursor for the synthesis of other substances such as heme (part of hemoglobin) and glutathione.

Therefore, glycine (option d) is the amino acid that is not used for the synthesis of hormones among the options provided

questions.text: Xanthurenic aciduria is seen in deficiency of?
questions.solution:
• Xanthurenic acid is formed when tryptophan metabolism is impaired due to a lack of vitamin B6. Normally, vitamin B6 is required as a coenzyme in the metabolism of tryptophan to niacin (vitamin B3).
  • In vitamin B6 deficiency, tryptophan metabolism shifts towards the production of xanthurenic acid instead of niacin. This leads to increased excretion of xanthurenic acid in the urine, which is characteristic of xanthurenic aciduria.

choices.text: Vitamin C and copper are needed for adequate cross linking
Most abundant amino acid is phenylalanine

questions.text: Which of the following not true about collagen?
questions.solution:
Most abundant amino acid is phenylalanine:

  • Not true. The most abundant amino acids in collagen are glycine, proline, and hydroxyproline, not phenylalanine. Glycine residues account for about one-third of the amino acids in collagen, while proline and hydroxyproline are also highly abundant due to their roles in stabilizing the collagen triple helix structure.

a. It is a fibrillary protein:

  • True. Collagen is indeed a fibrillary protein, characterized by its triple helical structure composed of three polypeptide chains (alpha chains) coiled around each other.

b. Vitamin C and copper are needed for adequate cross linking:

  • True. Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is essential for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues in collagen synthesis, which is critical for the proper formation of collagen fibrils. Copper is also involved in the cross-linking of collagen molecules, contributing to the stability and strength of collagen fibers.

d. Hydroxyproline and proline are found:

  • True. Hydroxyproline and proline are amino acids that are prominently found in collagen. Hydroxyproline is derived from proline through post-translational modification involving vitamin

questions.text: Correct order of draw of blood sample is?
questions.solution:
Option b. Clot activator - Citrate - EDTA - NaF matches the correct order of draw: clot activator tube first, followed by citrate tube, EDTA tube, and NaF tube.

The standard order of draw for blood collection tubes is generally as follows:

  1. Clot activator tube: This tube is used for serum tests and should generally be drawn first to minimize the risk of cross-contamination with other additives.
  2. Citrate tube: Contains sodium citrate and is used for coagulation studies (e.g., PT, PTT). It should be drawn second to ensure that residual anticoagulants from other tubes do not affect coagulation tests.
  3. NaF (Sodium Fluoride) tube: Contains NaF and is used for glucose testing. It should be drawn before EDTA tubes to prevent contamination with EDTA, which can affect some tests.
  4. EDTA tube: Contains EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) and is used for a variety of tests, including CBC (Complete Blood Count) and blood typing. It should be drawn last to minimize the risk of EDTA contamination in other tubes.

Order of blood draw can be memorized as follows:

CCS HEF

  • Culture
  • Citrate
  • Serum(Clot activator)
  • Heparin
  • EDTA
  • Fluoride

questions.text: A mother while kissing the child, finds the sweat of the child to salty. when genetic testing was conducted. CFTR gene was found to be mutated. Which of the following channels is affected?
questions.solution:
The condition described in the scenario where a child's sweat is unusually salty and genetic testing reveals a mutation in the CFTR gene points to cystic fibrosis (CF). Cystic fibrosis is caused by mutations in the CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) gene, which encodes a protein involved in ion transport across cell membranes.

CFTR protein functions as a chloride channel, regulating the movement of chloride ions across epithelial cell membranes. When CFTR is mutated, chloride ions cannot move properly, leading to thick, sticky mucus production in various organs, including the lungs, pancreas, and sweat glands.

Given the scenario:

  • Correct Answer: a. Chloride

Therefore, the mutation in the CFTR gene affects the chloride channel, resulting in increased chloride ion concentrations in sweat, which is a characteristic feature of cystic fibrosis.

questions.text:
Calculate the anion gap of the following results is achieved on ABG analysis
Na- 145 meq/L
K- 4 meq/L
Cl- 90 meq/L
HCO3- -20 meq/L
A drug reaction is to be performed in individuals with high fat diet. How much fat should be present in each meal of the subjects?
questions.solution:
The percentages of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins (lipids) in a typical diet can vary based on individual dietary habits and nutritional needs. Here are the general recommendations and ranges for each macronutrient:

  1. Carbohydrates: 45-65%
  2. Fats- 20-35%
  3. Protein- 10-35%

The amount of fat in a meal can affect the absorption of certain drugs, especially those that are lipophilic (fat-loving). High-fat meals can increase the absorption of such drugs. Typically, a high-fat meal is considered >35% fat..

Here, there is drug reaction so more drug absorbed due to high fat diet

questions.text: Severe vomiting leads to all except
questions.solution:
Severe vomiting can lead to several electrolyte and acid-base disturbances due to the loss of gastric acid and fluid. Let's analyze the possible effects listed:

a. Hypokalemia:

  • True. Vomiting can lead to loss of potassium (K^+) through the stomach, which can result in low potassium levels in the blood (hypokalemia). This can lead to muscle weakness, cardiac arrhythmias, and other complications.

b. Hypochloremia:

  • True. Vomiting can also result in loss of chloride ions (Cl^-), leading to hypochloremia. Chloride ions are lost along with gastric contents, contributing to electrolyte imbalances.

c. Metabolic acidosis:

  • True. Severe vomiting causes loss of gastric acid, which can lead to metabolic alkalosis initially due to the loss of hydrogen ions (H^+). However, if vomiting continues and bicarbonate (HCO3^-) is lost in excess relative to chloride, it can lead to metabolic acidosis.

d. Respiratory alkalosis:

  • False. Respiratory alkalosis is characterized by decreased carbon dioxide (CO2) levels and increased pH due to hyperventilation, not typically seen in vomiting.

questions.text:
Which of the following methods can detect the alterations in DNA sequence?
A. Restriction fragment length analysis
B. Flow cytometry
C. Pyrosequencing
D. FISH
questions.solution:
Option A: An inherited difference in the pattern of restriction enzyme digestion is known as a restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP). The differences in DNA sequence can result in variations of restriction sites and thus in the length of restriction fragments. So alteration of DNA sequences can be detected by RFLP.

Option B: Flow cytometry is a standard laser-based technology that is used in the detection and measurement of physical and chemical characteristics of cells or particles in a heterogeneous fluid mixture.

Option C: Pyrosequencing is second generation sequencing technique enabled the sequencing of DNA molecules.

Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) is a robust platform that has enabled the sequencing of thousands to millions of DNA molecules simultaneously. Next-generation sequencing (NGS), also known as high-throughput sequencing, is the catch-all term used to describe a number of different modern sequencing technologies.

The generations it is classified into include:

First Generation: Sanger Sequencing

Second Generation Sequencing: Pyrosequencing, Sequencing by Reversible Terminator Chemistry, Sequencing by Ligation

Third Generation Sequencing: Single Molecule Fluorescent Sequencing, Single Molecule Real Time Sequencing, Semiconductor Sequencing, Nanopore Sequencing

Fourth Generation Sequencing aims conducting genomic analysis directly in the cell.

Pyrosequencing

This method amplifies DNA inside water droplets in an oil solution (emulsion PCR), with each droplet containing a single DNA template attached to a single primer-coated bead that then forms a clonal colony.

The sequencing machine contains many picolitre-volume wells each containing a single bead and sequencing enzymes.

Pyrosequencing uses luciferase to generate light for detection of the individual nucleotides added to the nascent DNA, and the combined data are used to generate sequence read-outs.

This technology provides intermediate read length and price per base compared to Sanger sequencing on one end and Solexa and SOLiD on the other.

Option D: FISH are used for gene localization.

Gene localization can define a map of the human genome, which is useful in obtaining many information in the definition of human disease. Somatic cell hybridization and in situ hybridization are two techniques used for gene localization.

In in situ hybridization, a radioactive probe is added to a metaphase spread of chromosomes on a glass slide. The exact area of hybridization is localized by layering photographic emulsion over the slide and, after exposure, lining up the grains with some histologic identification of the chromosome.

Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), which utilizes fluorescent rather than radioactively labelled probes, is a very sensitive technique that is also used for this purpose. This often places the gene at a location on a given band or region on the chromosome.

questions.text: 12 years old boy with type 1 DM presents with unconsciousness. His urine is subjected to a test and the results is shown below. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
Option A: Rothera’s test used to detect ketone bodies in urine (ketonuria). It will be positive in ketosis due to starvation or uncontrolled DM.

DIABETIC KETOACIDOSIS (DKA)

This condition is caused by increased fatty acid metabolism and the accumulation of ketoacids (acetone, acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate).

DKA usually occurs in type 1 DM (Insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus) in association with cessation of insulin or an intercurrent illness such as an infection, gastroenteritis etc which increases insulin requirements temporarily and acutely, and is characterized by hyperglycemia, ketosis and a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Higher than normal quantities of ketone bodies present in the blood or urine constitute ketonemia (hyperketonemia) or ketonuria, respectively. The overall condition is called ketosis.

Ketosis can occur in uncontrolled DM as well as in starvation also. Ketosis in starvation occur due to depletion of available carbohydrate coupled with mobilization of FFA. This is associated with low blood sugar level and negative benedict’s test.

Option B: Fouchet's test is used to detect bile pigment like bilirubin in urine.

Option C: Benedict’s test is used to detect reducing substances like glucose. This test is positive when glucose is present in urine (glycosuria) in uncontrolled DM.

Option D: Seliwanoff's test is used to detect keto sugar Eg: fructose

Other tests commonly used to detect biochemical parameters:

Heat coagulation test used to detect protein in urine (proteinuria).

Van den Bergh test (reaction) used to detect bilirubin.

Ehrlich's Reaction is used to detect urobilinogen in urine.

Schlesinger's Reaction is used to detect urobilin.

questions.text: A patient came with C/O muscle weakness to OPD. Doctor found that he has cardiomyopathy and diagnosed him to be a case of Barth syndrome, where patient has mitochondrial dysfunction. What is the defect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cardiolipin is a diphosphatidic glycerol, which is found only in mitochondria and is essential for the mitochondrial function. Phosphatidic acid is a precursor of phosphatidylglycerol, which in turn gives rise to cardiolipin. Decreased cardiolipin levels or alterations in its structure or metabolism cause mitochondrial dysfunction in aging and in pathologic conditions including heart failure, hypothyroidism, and Barth syndrome (cardioskeletal myopathy).

Option B: Phosphatidylethanolamine (cephalin) and phosphatidylserine (found in most tissues) are also found in cell membranes and differ from phosphatidylcholine only in that ethanolamine or serine, respectively, replaces choline. Phosphatidylserine also plays a role in apoptosis (programmed cell death).

Option C: Phosphatidylcholines, commonly called lecithins are the most abundant phospholipids of the cell membrane and represent a large proportion of the body’s store of choline. Choline is important in nervous transmission, as acetyl choline, and as a store of labile methyl groups.

Dipalmitoyl lecithin (Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl choline) is a very effective surface-active agent and a major constituent of the surfactant preventing adherence, due to surface tension, of the inner surfaces of the lungs. Its absence from the lungs of premature infants causes respiratory distress syndrome.

Option D: Lysophospholipids are intermediate in the metabolism of phosphoglycerols. These are phosphoacylglycerols containing only one acyl radical, for example, lysophosphatidylcholine (lysolecithin), which is important in the metabolism and interconversion of phospholipids. This compound is also found in oxidized lipoproteins and has been implicated in some of their effects in promoting atherosclerosis.

Sphingomyelins are found in the outer leaflet of the cell membrane lipid bilayer and are particularly abundant in specialized areas of the plasma membrane known as lipid rafts. They are also found in large quantities in the myelin sheath that surrounds nerve fibers. They are believed to play a role in cell signaling and in apoptosis. Sphingomyelins contain no glycerol, and on hydrolysis they yield a fatty acid, phosphoric acid, choline, and sphingosine. The combination of sphingosine plus fatty acid is known as ceramide, a structure also found in the glycosphingolipids.

questions.text: In Pompe's disease, the enzyme deficient is?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lysosomal α1 → 4 and α1 → 6 glucosidase (Acid maltase) deficiency leads to Pompe’s disease which is characterized by accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes: juvenile-onset variant, muscle hypotonia, death from heart failure by age 2; adult-onset variant, muscle dystrophy.

Option B: Muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency leads to McArdle syndrome which is characterized by Poor exercise tolerance; muscle glycogen abnormally high; blood lactate very low after exercise.

Option C: Muscle and erythrocyte phosphofructokinase 1 deficiency lead to Tarui disease, which is characterized by Poor exercise tolerance; abnormally high muscle glycogen (2.5-4%); blood lactate very low after exercise and hemolytic anemia.

Option D: Lactate dehydrogenase is an enzyme involved in anaerobic glycolysis. Under anaerobic conditions, the NADH cannot be reoxidized through the respiratory chain, and pyruvate is reduced to lactate catalyzed by lactate dehydrogenase.

A rare genetic glycogen storage disease characterized by either lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) M- or H-subunit deficiency.

Lactate dehydrogenase A deficiency (sometimes called glycogen storage disease XI) characterized by LDH M-subunit deficiency. Individual have exertional fatigue and muscle pain, cramps during exercise (exercise intolerance), can be accompanied by rhabdomyolysis and myoglobinuria.

Lactate dehydrogenase-B deficiency: Individuals with this type typically do not exhibit any signs or symptoms related to the condition. They do not experience difficulty with physical activity or specific physical features associated with the deficiency.

Glycogen storage Diseases

Glycogen storage disease is a generic term to describe a group of inherited disorders characterized by deposition of an abnormal type or quantity of glycogen in tissues, or failure to mobilize glycogen.

questions.text:
Arrange the steps of Karyotyping in order:
i. Collect cells by peripheral vein using heparin syringe.
ii. Culture in phytohaemagglutinin.
iii. Incubation at 37°C for 3 days.
iv. Harvest with colchicine.
v. Routine staining with giemsa
questions.solution: Karyotyping is a method of chromosome analysis, commonly used in cytogenetic laboratory to analyse chromosomal constitution of an individual, which is known as a karyotype.

questions.text: Ketone bodies are not utilised by liver because it lacks
questions.solution:
Option A: Thiokinase (also known as succinyl coenzyme A synthetase or succinate thiokinase) is an enzyme involved in citric acid cycle. It catalyzes the reversible reaction of succinyl-CoA to succinate.

Option B: Thiophorase is an enzyme involved in utilization of ketone bodies (Ketolysis). Liver actively produces ketone bodies, but it lacks enzyme Thiophorase, therefore liver is unable to use ketone bodies as fuel.

Steps of Ketolysis (Ketone body utilization)

Option C: Thiotransferase not involved in ketone body metabolism.

Option D: Thiolase is also involved in utilization of ketone bodies (Ketolysis) as well as in beta oxidation of fatty acid. It breakdown acetoacetyl CoA into two acetyl CoA.

questions.text: Template DNA strand is 5'CATTCAATATCGATC3'. Resulting mRNA sequence after transcription right is?
questions.solution:
Option A & Option B: The process by which RNA is synthesized from the DNA is called Transcription.

The strand that is transcribed or copied to the mRNA is referred to as Template strand. The opposite strand is referred to as Coding strand or Non-template strand.

Primary transcript (mRNA) is complementary to the template strand. So sequence of coding strand is similar to nascent mRNA except in the case of Thymine replaced by Uracil.

Here

Template strand sequence is: 5' CATTCAATATCGATC 3'

Coding strand sequence will be: 3' GTAAGTTATAGCTAG 5'

mRNA transcript will be: 3' GUAAGUUAUAGCUAG 5'

It can also be written as, 5' GAUCGAUAUUGAAUG 3'

Option C & Option D: Here we have to find resulting mRNA sequence after transcription, so all option containing T (thymine) cannot be answer.

Note:

In the case of a double-stranded DNA molecule containing many genes, the template strand for each gene will not necessarily be the same strand of the DNA double helix. Genes can be transcribed off both strands of DNA. Thus, a given strand of a double stranded DNA molecule will serve as the template strand for some genes and the coding strand of other genes. The information in the template strand is read out in the 3′-5′ direction.
